title: Did ancient humans ever have some form of gills? - Quora

response.answer_text: Did ancient humans ever have some form of gills? TL/DL: No. Longer answer: The “Aquatic ape hypothesis” as it is called, is the largest load of Bovinae feces ever to be unloaded on the scientific community. Which is why it is not supported by the scientific community. It makes as much sense as the flat earth movement in that there is “some evidence” when you stretch that evidence and ignore other explanations that have further evidence to back them up. Predecessors of mammals had gills, so embryos pass through a stage where they have something that resembles gills. At this same stage most land life all looks the same, lizard, bird, mammal, higher, lower, no matter how you qualify it, we all show our ancestral roots by going through this stage. So, no, that does not in any way demonstrate evidence of an aquatic ape ancestor of man. A more recent ancestor would show evidence of these traits much more noticeably. We see demonstratable evidence of the mating of Neanderthal and Denisovan into the human stock even though it makes up only 2–4% of our genetic make-up. What does it mean to have Neanderthal or Denisovan DNA? In addition to the percentage of Neanderthal or Denisovan DNA, direct to-consumer testing reports may include information about a few genetic variants inherited from these ancestors that influence specific traits. Studies have suggested that certain genetic variations inherited from archaic humans may play roles in hair texture, height, sensitivity of the sense of smell, immune responses, adaptations to high altitude, and other characteristics in modern humans. These variations may also influence the risk of developing certain diseases. However, the significance of Neanderthal or Denisovan genetic variants on disease risk is still an area of active study, and most direct-to-consumer test results currently do not include them. We have a reasonable grasp on the history of human evolution. Even to our ape ancestors. So no sneaking in an aquatic ape.  By Dbachmann - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, File:Hominini lineage.svg You can look at just the Homo line and there is no sneaking in any aquatic species.  By User:Conquistador, User:Dbachmann - updated version of File:Homo-Stammbaum, Version Stringer-en.svg, CC BY-SA 4.0, File:Homo lineage 2017update.svg You might say, “yeah, but sure, but couldn’t the aquatic ape have been the missing link that everyone keeps talking about?” To which I would answer… “Sigh…. What missing link?”  So… no, no hominid had gills. You have to go back to when all life came from the ocean to find when all life had gills. Those were not hominids. That was when fish first walked on land and developed lungs and lost gills.

Did ancient humans ever have some form of gills? Short answer = No. Slightly longer answer = No, as ancient humans were humans, and, their ancestors were earlier hominids, and their ancestors were earlier primates, and their ancestors were earlier mammals, and their ancestors were earlier amniotes… and their ancestors were earlier reptiles. The ancestors of the earlier reptiles though, were earlier amphibians, and, some of those had gills, especially in their younger stages, such as tadpoles, salamanders, etc. The ancestors of the earlier amphibians were earlier fish, and these had gills in their adult stages. :D

Did ancient humans ever have some form of gills? I can’t imagine how anyone could think that a primate ever had gills. The ancestors of land-based animals emigrated from the sea approximately a billion years ago. Mammals have existed for only some 100 million years and primates did not emerge until about 6 1/5 million years ago. What on earth would mammals do with gills that would be completely useless for the past 100 million years—or what would their ancestors do with them in the roughly previous 900 million years? Many charts and description of how life evolved on our planet and the timelines involved are available in many places on the web.

All land vertebrates have basic gills as embryos. These go on to form jaw bones. But functional gills were lost long ago. Note that tadpoles have inefficient external gills. These must have re-evolved early on land for amphibians.

Yes, in theory. We see this gill development stage passed through in the human embryo as it grows. The theory of recapitulation, also called the biogenetic law or embryological parallelism—often expressed using Ernst Haeckel's phrase "ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny" … is a historical hypothesis that the development of the embryo of an animal, from fertilization to gestation or hatching (ontogeny), goes through stages resembling or representing successive adult stages in the evolution of the animal's remote ancestors (phylogeny). It was formulated in the 1820s by Étienne Serres based on the work of Johann Friedrich Meckel, after whom it is also known as Meckel–Serres law.
By the time the primates that we call “human” existed our ancestors had long, long ago lost their gills, so no. Lungs evolved from the tissue sac around the gills or the gills or both.
